headline: How Much Oil Does Venezuela Really Have? For Chevron, the Truth Matters.
summary: Investors are raising doubts about how much oil Venezuela really has and whether it could be profitably extracted.  Venezuela’s oil has long been tantalizing—and problematic.  The term “proved reserves” represents oil deemed recoverable under certain technical and economic assumptions, but not necessarily oil that can be produced quickly or cheaply.

raw.headline: How Much Oil Does Venezuela Really Have? For Chevron, the Truth Matters.

headline: Why Venezuela’s Oil May Be Far More Trouble Than It Is Worth for Chevron and Other Companies
summary: President Donald Trump wants U.S. companies to rebuild Venezuela’s oil industry, but Venezuelan oil can’t simply be turned back on.  Chevron Exxon Mobil  and  ConocoPhillips  have long histories in the country, though only Chevron operates there now.  In theory, those companies could turn Venezuela into a gusher, ramping up the country’s production of 1 million barrels a day now.

raw.headline: Why Venezuela’s Oil May Be Far More Trouble Than It Is Worth for Chevron and Other Companies
raw.summary: President Donald Trump wants U.S. companies to rebuild Venezuela’s oil industry, but Venezuelan oil can’t simply be turned back on.  Chevron Exxon Mobil  and  ConocoPhillips  have long histories in the country, though only Chevron operates there now.  In theory, those companies could turn Venezuela into a gusher, ramping up the country’s production of 1 million barrels a day now.

headline: Trump administration sets meetings with oil firms on Venezuela: source
summary: STORY: Donald Trump's administration is planning to meet with executives from U.S. oil companies later this week.That's according to a Reuters source, who says the meetings are to discuss boosting Venezuelan oil production after U.S. forces ousted country leader Nicolas Maduro.The administration is eyeing getting U.S. oil companies back into the South American nation, after its government took control of U.S.-led energy operations there nearly two decades ago. The White House did not comment on the planned meetings.But said it believed U.S. industry was ready to move into Venezuela.The three biggest U.S. oil companies - Exxon Mobil, ConocoPhillips and Chevron - did not immediately respond to requests for comment.According to four industry executives, the three firms have not yet had any conversations with the administration about Maduro's ouster.That contradicts Trump's statements over the weekend.The president said he had already held meetings with all the U.S. oil companies, both before and after Maduro was seized.Trump also said that he expects the firms to spend billions of dollars to boost Venezuela's oil production.But industry analysts say those plans will face challenges.They cite lack of infrastructure, and deep uncertainty over the country’s political future and legal framework, as well as doubts over long-term U.S. policy.

headline: Trump Tells NBC He May Reimburse Venezuela Oil Investments
summary: Trump said the project to have US oil industry companies expand their operations in the country could be “up and running” in less than 18 months, in an interview Monday with NBC News — a timeframe starkly at odds with estimates from energy industry experts, while oil companies have been largely silent about their willingness to reinvest in Venezuela.  “I think we can do it in less time than that, but it’ll be a lot of money,” Trump told NBC.

raw.headline: Trump Tells NBC He May Reimburse Venezuela Oil Investments
raw.summary: Trump said the project to have US oil industry companies expand their operations in the country could be “up and running” in less than 18 months, in an interview Monday with NBC News — a timeframe starkly at odds with estimates from energy industry experts, while oil companies have been largely silent about their willingness to reinvest in Venezuela.  “I think we can do it in less time than that, but it’ll be a lot of money,” Trump told NBC.
